captions.text:
MATT FARAH: Though the factory
shut down almost 30 years ago,

and the car's creator has died,
at least one man works

tirelessly to keep
the dream alive.

His name is Don, and he's the
only DeLorean-certified

mechanic working in
the US today.

Here is his shop,
DMC California.
But first some background.

When I was a little kid, the
DeLorean changed my life.

The first time I ever saw one
was the second I learned that

a car could be more than just
a mode of transportation.

From the unpainted
Guigiaro-styled stainless

steel body to the low, wide
stance, its starring movie

role, and the open doors
extending to the sky,

everything about the DeLorean
seemed right to a
four-year-old kid.

I only later learned of the
troubles that followed John

DeLorean and, subsequently,
the car's performance.

A walk through DMC reveals every
conceivable part you

could need to replace on a
DeLorean, from wheels to

complete body panels, engines,
never-used, original stock

transmissions, and
even chassis.

Outside sat more DeLorean
cars than I've
ever seen in one place.

I immediately wondered how Don
and his staff could identify
one from another.

DON STEGER: There was one time
that I counted all the cars.

We've had 40 cars here on the
property at one time.

I've probably got about
20 here today.

But we make sure-- we have a key
code up there, and every

spot in the shop has a specific
location where every
key goes for which car.
So we don't make any mistakes.

This place exists because John
DeLorean had a dream.
And he built the car.
And went over to Ireland.

Had them mass-produced
over there.

From the beginning to the end,
it took five years to make the

plant, and they had them
rolling off there.
And this was his dream car.

I personally got to meet John,
and I told him I'll do

whatever I can to keep
them on the road.

MATT FARAH: But I didn't just
come here for the tour.

I came here to find out the
answer to a question I've had
for a long time.
Can you make a DeLorean fast?

One of Don's customers seems
to have the answer.
All right.
Here we go.
The world's fastest DeLorean.

And it has one of the hardest
clutches I've ever used.

So, Kenny Duttweiler twin turbo
Buick Grand National V6.

Now I will admit that I have
talked to several people about

doing a motor swap into a
DeLorean because I've always
loved the styling of it.

Love the look of the car, love
the idea of the car.

But everyone knows the stock PRV
engine in this thing is a
pile of crap.

And it's not a pile of crap
because it's a bad engine.

It just doesn't make
any power.

Most people know of the PRV
engine as the motor that you
can find in a Volvo 240.

And it makes an amazing
130 horsepower.
This car makes 575 horsepower.

So let's put our foot on it
and see what happens.
Makes a cool sound.
That's for sure.

I mean, it's not blowing me away
with the speed right now.
It's not.

It's definitely faster
than the original.

When I drove the original
DeLorean, I raced a minivan on

a racetrack and got positively
smoked by the
Toyota Sienna minivan.
DON STEGER: I tell you what.

That's one of things in the
beginning that John DeLorean
really wanted.

I mean, he put the PRV engine in
there with 130 horsepower.

Then we started getting
into cams and headers
and stuff like that.

So little by little,
we're getting more
horsepower out of it.
This is pretty scary to drive.
I'm serious.
Every time I get done--

I don't know how you will be--
but when I get done driving

this, if I get on it a little a
few times, I get out of the
car shaking.

Because it's like a
little slot car.

You give it that gas, and you
better just make sure you know
where you're going.

You know, I've been doing
this for 30 years.

That's all I do is
just DeLoreans.

As far as the suspension,
with this car, I've
never had an issue.
He takes it on the racetrack.

I've got people racing in
Florida with twin turbos.

Because of the power, they're
keeping up with some of the
best cars out there.

As far as the frames, I mean,
it's designed to crush as you
get in an accident.

So the front is a little
on the weak side.

But they do have a front recall
kit for them that
reinforces that.

The number one thing with the
DeLoreans is just the

uniqueness, the style,
the sleekness.

I mean, you've got the wishbone
frame front and rear.

Fuel tanks in the front,
engine in the back.
It's all encased.

You get the gull-wing doors,
the stainless steel.

I mean, these are
things that--

I mean, the car's
30 years old.
Still looks just as good.

You can put it up against any
brand new car today, and

people will probably take more
pictures of the DeLorean than
they will a brand-new car.

MATT FARAH: You know, now people
my age, 30 years old,

the late 20s, early 30s, now
guys like us who grew up with

Back to the Future, who grew
up seeing these cars on

posters when we were kids, now
that we can afford them, now

that we can actually afford
these cars, I think they're
going to be collector's items.

And I think if you can find
one at a good price today,

you'd do well to buy it
and keep it and hold
on to it for a while.

But let's try and give a little
more juice to that.

Yeah, it was definitely breaking
up at the top of the
power band there.

Don told me this car had been
sitting for quite a few months
before we took it out today.

He said it was a nice excuse
to give it some exercise.

I think it might need a little
bit of tuning work.

Turns out the car had been
sitting for about six months

until I called up and asked to
drive it, and old fuel had
gummed up the lines.

The more I drove, the
worse it got.

DON STEGER: It's all
sticky, gooey.

MATT FARAH: Would that have
been helped with some fuel
stabilizer, maybe?

DON STEGER: Yeah, you
need to solidify it.
Need to loosen it up, yes.

MATT FARAH: Banana peels
and Miller beer.

This DeLorean that runs on
gas, that's bullshit.
Without a Mr. Fusion--

Don worked his magic on the
downed DMC, trying to clear

out the sludge in the fuel lines
by flushing them with

fresh gas and adjusting a hose
so it wouldn't crimp.
And for a minute, it worked.
DON STEGER: [INAUDIBLE].

MATT FARAH: Feels
all right, man.

DON STEGER: If you can make it
to the gas station and put

fresh gas in there, it helps
clean it all up.
MATT FARAH: Let's try that.
DON STEGER: OK.

MATT FARAH: He straightened out
the $100 hose to help it
flow better.

And now we're going to fill it
up with cold gas, like from

the ground, which should
circulate the fuel a little

better, hopefully make it
run a little better.

DON STEGER: And the
gummy stuff--

brand-new fuel will help break
up the gummy stuff.

MATT FARAH: And brand-new
fuel will help break
up the gummy stuff.
All right.
Let's see.
Come on, baby, 575 horsepower.
No.
No, it's not.
That's flat right now.

Nah, it's breaking
up quite a bit.

It was done for, and
time to call AAA.

I guess the moral of the story
is, if you have a car with a

one-off 20-year-old motor swap
in it, you might want to
maintain it.

You might want to make sure
everything's running with the

gas, put some fuel
stabilizer in it.

Because otherwise, things
like this can happen.

And when you're driving a very
unique, engine-swapped car,

unfortunately things like this
frequently do happen.

Which is why, when I buy
my DeLorean, I'm
going to leave it stock.

Maybe put an exhaust, maybe
a little bolt-ons here and

there, but I don't
need all that.
I can appreciate the shape.

I can appreciate how it
feels to sit in it.
It makes me feel like a kid.
And I still love DeLoreans.

And when I do buy one, I'm going
to buy one from Don at
DMC Garden Grove.

And I'd like to thank them for
coming on the show, trying to

share a car with me, showing
me around their shop.

And next week on Tuned, we are
going to be going to a runway
for a tuner car shootout.

You're not going to
want to miss that.

Mondays, only on the
Drive network.

So until then, I'm Matt Farah,
and we'll be waiting for AAA.

comments.text:
PRV V6 was only in the 260(sometimes)/760(used here the most)/960(very very 
rare), and a few GLE x40's.

Otherwise, you got the iron red-block 4 cylinder. The the use of the PRV 
for Volvo was more of a transition motor. Volvo was using red-blocks with 
pushrods until early 80's, then they switched to using OHC for the same 
blocks.﻿

comments.author: paul williams

comments.text:
+SES10M I know what ethanol is and how it's made, etc. I agree with you 
that ethanol is a good solution, but the politics surrounding the whole 
thing are what's causing us to not run on ethanol. The oil industry, the 
failure of biodiesel, the cost to convert cars and gas stations to ethanol, 
Dubai's economy, where the hell are we supposed to plant all this corn, and 
competing with other better alternatives like electric cars (which hold the 
land speed record) or hemp fuel which is cheaper to produce, easier to 
produce, more efficient to produce, and better for the soil than corn aka 
ethanol.
Also, I see what you're saying. Ethanol has lower gas mileage but it's so 
damn cheap to produce and buy it just doesn't make any sense to run on oil 
anymore.
Though I think ethanol is a very good solution to the problems we have 
today, with environmental standards and inflated gas prices, etc. I think 
hemp fuel is a better alternative for the average consumer, and electric 
cars are a better solution for performance cars.
Ethanol is definitely the middle ground here but we're not all united yet. 
Until ethanol starts setting land speed records or we find a way to produce 
electricity cheaper than we can produce oil, there won't be a new standard 
for a long time.
Not to mention, electric cars may have no emissions but power plants do. If 
everybody converts to electric, the amount of power nuclear plants will 
have to produce will inevitably warm the globe considerably.
Hemp fuel may be the cheapest and most environmentally friendly option, but 
it's not necessarily the best for performance vehicles.
And while ethanol may be great for saving money, it's also not good for 
performance. Not at all.
But I think everybody can agree on one thing. Oil is the absolute worst 
option we have at the moment.
comments.author: WeActOnImpulse Official

comments.text:
+WeActOnImpulse Official Ethanol Always cones with lower gas milage, I use 
Ethanol E85 in my LS1 wich is a 1994 engine, you just need to set it up, 
but at the long term its cheaper and better, ethanol could help 
manufacturers like GM and Ford to avoid the CAFE law, yes the same rule 
that forced the new ZO6 to have a supercharger 6.2L instead of a 7L with 
direct injection or a V6 twin turbo instead of a v8, america will keep 
lossing its veloved v8s if they keep using regular gas.... and most 
Americans are ingorant about Ethanol and they think ethaon is made from 
food... or ethanol is bad for cars... they actually think ethanol price is 
higher than current gas, or ethanol polute same as regular gas... ethanol 
is the perfect future for combustion engines, but people are so ignorant 
and blind by companies to see it,
comments.author: SES10M

comments.text:
+SES10M An engine that's built for ethanol is going to drive just fine. 
Ethanol is a viable fuel alternative and it's good. The problem is putting 
ethanol in cars that aren't meant for ethanol. Bad things happen, like 
lower gas mileage, gas going bad, and gunking up the fuel injection system.

comments.text:

ethanol actually is the reason our gas goes bad that quickly. however, the 
problem it causes with engines is more likely from rubber fuel lines. 
because ethanol has a reaction with rubber that has poor effects on 
engines. can an engine survive ethanol fine? yes. do old engines do it 
well? no. does that make them bad? also no

comments.author: CaptainYodelstein

comments.text:
I'd like to see someone squeeze all the power out of the stock 2.8 as they 
could. Port the heads/intake, custom grind cam, custom headers/exhaust and 
a tune. I'm sure with some machine shop time you could double the hp/tq and 
keep it reliable and fairly original. They had a limited edition stock 
turbo V6, I bet with work you could make a decent amount of power with that.

Engine swaps are great, but I like to see what potential a stock engine has 
to give before I go scrap it. The old 305 in my truck was (and still is) 
pretty weak, but with headers/exhaust, TB port smoothing and a tune, it 
helped a lot, gave it the power of a stock 350 but for a lot less. 
Eventually it'll get a 350 with those mods but I'm saving money by keeping 
the stock engine as long as I can. ﻿

comments.text:
I guess horsepower was limited for a while in a lot of cars due to fuel 
costs and such?  It's like they wanted every car in the 80's to look like 
shit too or something.  I had a 91 pontiac sunbird, that thing was so 
behind in looks, such a piece of shit with my 3 forward gears. The heater 
core was messed up and I don't know why they engineered it that way but it 
vented antifreeze steam into the incoming fan air, I would drive it for a 
while and my eyes would get bloodshot and I'd feel like shit, had no idea. 
fastest car I've ever had is my current civic, all it's got is stock vtec, 
doesn't feel so fast, I think I just drive it hard all the time and that's 
why I often beat regular traffic.  120 horsepower or around there I 
believe, but I can get good mileage if I drive it that way, which I don't

comments.text:
The Delorean that Jerry Seinfeld drove with Patton Oswald in an episode of 
"Comedians In Cars Getting Coffee" broke down as well. I'm almost positive 
that they borrowed their Delorean from this same guy in LA because when it 
broke down, a replacement Delorean was brought to them as the broken down 
one was towed away. I love the aesthetics of Deloreans, but they truly are 
POS's. ﻿

Personally, when I was kid these cars were cool just because they had 
gull-wing doors. I didn't care about stainless steel panels then or now. 
Overall the styling is kind of dated even by early nineties standards. No 
offense to the creators or admirers but if you really want to take notice 
of cars that looked truelly ahead of their time and still look pretty good 
today the Countach or Pantera are some of the first that come to mind and 
they actually performed pretty good to...
DeLorean, is nothing with out a flux capacitor.﻿

comments.author: alesillo Apellido

comments.text:
All of Deloreans designs are classic.  GTO, Firebird, Trans Am as well as 
the DMC.  The 1982 TA is my dream car, Knight Rider stole my heart before 
BTTF, and if Delorean had his way it'd have had a 10-cylinder Maserati 
built engine and not the weak "cowl-inducted" Chevy 305 that GM demanded be 
put in.  It's funny how Bumblebee is the trendy car of choice for old dudes 
and teenage girls now but it would not have ever existed if Delorean didn't 
first design the Firebird behind GMs back.  The car was so close to 
production ready that GM brass let Pontiac and Delorean go ahead if Chevy 
got a crack at the design and they ended up bringing a scaled down version 
to market first.  

It seemed like the big auto makers pulled out all their pocket politicians 
to ensure the EPA took all the limited power that the DMC had out of the US 
models.  It's too bad, the Euro models seemed decent enough and I'm sure if 
they had a few more years to work things out, later model cars could have 
been pretty great.  Delorean was always a rebel and that's what I always 
respected and liked about he guy.  In the process he gave us the most 
iconic cars ever.  To me that's his legacy not that drug nonsense.﻿

comments.author: MrKnnknn

comments.text:
Pity he didn't go into the DeLorean story, I think it's the best part of 
the car:
Built in Northern Ireland during the middle of the Troubles when no-one 
would go near the place.  Thatcher brokered a deal with DeLorean, 
effectively paying him to manufacture there.  It all ended in a big 
embarrassing mess of cocaine and cash.

Loads of guys who worked for DMC are still knocking about.  My neighbor 
used to be one of the guys who drove-in all the new cars.  Just drove them 
'round the block to see if the wheels stayed on' to quote him.  

They still hold a huge legend status in NI.  We're oddly very proud of 
making a very iconic yet pretty shite car...﻿
